title.value: A case–control study on predicting population risk of suicide using health administrative data: a research protocol
title.justification: The title is extracted from the heading of the paper.
title.quote: A case–control study on predicting population risk of suicide using health administrative data: a research protocol

extractions.description: This research paper aims to develop sex-specific risk predictive models for population risk of suicide, to be used by policy and decision makers. The models are trained using health administrative data, statistical regression, and machine learning techniques in order to predict population risk of suicide at the national, provincial, and regional levels in Quebec, Canada.

type.justification: The paper is based on a case–control study design using quantitative and qualitative data to develop predictive models.
type.quote: Methods and analysis A case–control study design will be used to develop sex-­specific risk predictive models for population risk of suicide, using statistical regression and machine learning techniques.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on developing predictive models using healthcare data to predict population risk of suicide.
name.quote: developing risk predictive models for population risk of suicide.

name.justification: The paper extensively uses machine learning techniques to develop predictive models.
name.quote: The quantitative research involved developing and validating risk prediction models for suicide using advanced ML and visualisation methods.

name.justification: The study uses epidemiological methods to collect and analyze population health data.
name.quote: Each year, over 4500 Canadians take their own life,1 and more than 700 000 people die because of suicide worldwide,2 imposing enormous impacts on families, communities and societies.

name.justification: The paper discusses the use of LASSO regression for feature selection in developing the predictive models.
name.quote: least absolute shrinkage and selection operator regression for feature selection.

aliases: Least Absolute Shrinkage and Selection Operator

is_contributed.justification: LASSO regression is not a new contribution; it is a well-known statistical method.
is_contributed.quote: least absolute shrinkage and selection operator regression

is_executed.justification: LASSO regression is a computationally intensive method, typically executed on CPU/GPU.
is_executed.quote: least absolute shrinkage and selection operator regression

is_compared.justification: LASSO regression is mentioned among other models for comparison.
is_compared.quote: ML techniques such as logistic regression, random forest, XGBoost and multilayer perceptron

referenced_paper_title.justification: There is no specific referenced paper mentioned for LASSO Regression in the text.

name.justification: Random Forest is listed as one of the machine learning models used in the study.
name.quote: We will develop supervised learning models such as logistic regression, random forest, XGBoost and multilayer perceptron

is_contributed.justification: Random Forest is a well-established machine learning model and not a new contribution of this paper.

is_executed.justification: Random Forests are typically executed on CPUs/GPUs for training and predictions.
is_executed.quote: We will develop supervised learning models such as logistic regression, random forest, XGBoost and multilayer perceptron

is_compared.justification: The paper intends to compare Random Forest with other models like logistic regression and XGBoost.
is_compared.quote: We will develop supervised learning models such as logistic regression, random forest, XGBoost and multilayer perceptron with an optimised model architecture.

referenced_paper_title.justification: There is no specific referenced paper mentioned for Random Forest in the text.

is_contributed.justification: XGBoost is an existing machine learning model and not a new contribution by this paper.

is_executed.justification: XGBoost requires computational resources, commonly executed on CPUs/GPUs.
is_executed.quote: We will develop supervised learning models such as logistic regression, random forest, XGBoost and multilayer perceptron

is_compared.justification: The paper aims to compare XGBoost with other models like logistic regression and Random Forest.
is_compared.quote: We will develop supervised learning models such as logistic regression, random forest, XGBoost and multilayer perceptron

referenced_paper_title.justification: There is no specific referenced paper mentioned for XGBoost in the text.

is_contributed.justification: Logistic regression is a well-known statistical method and not a new contribution from this paper.

is_executed.justification: Logistic regression models are typically computationally executed on CPUs/GPUs.
is_executed.quote: We will develop supervised learning models such as logistic regression, random forest, XGBoost and multilayer perceptron

name.value: Quebec Integrated Chronic Disease Surveillance System (QICDSS)
name.justification: The paper uses data from QICDSS for developing predictive models.
name.quote: The QICDSS provided all the variables drawn from health administrative databases. It covers 98% of the Quebec’s population since 1996.

referenced_paper_title.value: Blais C, Jean S, Sirois C, et al. Quebec Integrated Chronic Disease Surveillance System (QICDSS), an innovative approach. Chronic Dis Inj Can 2014;34:226–35.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset's referenced paper is already cited in the document.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The QICDSS17 provided all the variables drawn from health administrative databases.

name.value: Canadian Urban Environmental Health Research Consortium (CANUE)
name.justification: The paper utilizes data from CANUE for community-level indicators.
name.quote: The CANUE data contain indicators for unemployment, social deprivation, access to health services and built environment at the community level, and can be linked with health administrative data by postal codes.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The specific referenced paper for CANUE is not mentioned in the text.
